ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of ethical theories; application to case-studies; critical thinking; argumentation

I learned a lot about the subject matter. I have a real understanding and vocabulary of some of the greatest economic thinkers and business ethicists. We spend a lot of time on corporate personhood, surveillance capitalism, and woke capitalism which I think is important for every student to learn about.
A comprehensive application of major ethical theories to business activities.

So much! The aim of the course is to prompt students to critically think about "how the incentive structure of market exchange encourages businesses to commodify social relations in a way that raises moral questions about the pursuit of profit." The first few weeks of the course focus on creating a strong foundation for the four central ethical theories of the class: Aristotelian virtue ethics, Kantian deontology, utilitarianism, and Lockean property rights. Then the rest of the course allows students to use those ethical theories (and their own moral judgments) to analyze various specific business ethic issues, such as surveillance capitalism (privacy invasion at the hands of tech giants like Google and Facebook), "woke" capitalism, and sweatshops. You'll learn so much about each issue and, because Professor Collins is so intentional about assigning readings that cover a wide breadth of perspectives, you'll leave each class with a matured take on each. It's one thing to believe sweatshops are unethical, but it's another thing to be able to explain *why* you find sweatshops are unethical through a deontological lens or as part of an educated critique of free market capitalism (and it's highly possible you'll leave that class session thinking sweatshops aren't as unethical as you initially felt...). Through written reading responses, in-class discussions, a debate, and two papers, you will sharpen your ability to construct and present a strong ethical, political, and economic argument and respond to counter-arguments.
N/a
My understanding of contemporary business ethics increased significantly and I was introduced to a much more faithful interpretation of utilitarianism than I have seen anywhere else.
Course covered relevant ethical theories in depth before applying them to a number of economic topics

As someone who was unfamiliar with business terms and concepts prior to taking this course, it provided a solid introduction to important concepts such as shareholder and stakeholder theory, corporate social responsibility, and the merits and demerits of both. Professor Collins did a great job at helping us connect concepts from week to week, and the course overall felt very unified. By the end, I felt like I had a solid grasp on some of the most pressing business dilemmas, including surveillance capitalism, religious liberty, and price gouging, and could analyze each from different ethical lenses, including Kantianism and Utilitarianism.

I learned about current dilemmas in business ethics and how capitalism has led to the commodification of social relations. I developed writing skills as I had to write philosophy papers that considered multiple frameworks and applied them to the questions we discussed in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: excellent syllabus, passionate professor
Weaknesses: significantly more reading than any other of my seminars, please consider lowering

Really interesting readings and case studies  I personally am never a fan of quote ID's on in-class exams, since I think that there are better ways of testing student knowledge, but that's a small gripe.
N/a
Strength: The course is driven by student discussion and Prof. Collins teaches it in a very objective manner. Weakness: It would be helpful to have more slides available summarizing the content.

Strengths: Prof. Collins is more on top of things than 99% of Yale instructors, and I really appreciated that
Weaknesses: I think it would have helped to spread out the early weeks' ethical material across another week or two and spend a little less time on the cases studies (by the end, it kind of felt like our sense of Locke and Aristotle was mostly faded, so applying them wasn't so productive)

Strengths: Even if you are somewhat unfamiliar with prominent ethical theories like kantianism and utilitarianism or need a refresher, this class spends just enough time laying the foundational theoretical knowledge so that you will be able to apply these theories to the issues you later analyze. The readings for this class were incredibly interesting, and in-class discussions highlighted some of the key tensions between the authors.

Strengths: great selection of readings that provides both a theoretical framework to analyze pressing questions in business ethics as well as diverse perspectives on those dilemmas. There was significant constructive feedback to improve my writing.

Weaknesses: Sometimes the discussions in the seminar felt unorganized and repetitive

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! Corporations run the world. Anyone seeking to lead a successful career and life needs to be aware of the related systems/laws/controversies.

I would if you are interested in the subject matter and like to do reading. There was a good amount of pretty dense reading, court cases, etc. Collins also demands a lot from his students and therefore the class demands a lot of work and effot. This is the opposite of a gut.
yes collins is AMAZING.
Yes, Professor Collins is an amazing teacher
Yes! If you're interested in critical engagement with ethics and business activities (whether you're intensely skeptical or very pro-business), you'll get a lot out of this seminar.

Yes, a million times yes! This class is undoubtedly in my top 3 favorites that I've taken over my six semesters at Yale. The material of the class is by far some of the most interesting I've encountered during my time in college. I was so excited each week to unpack the readings with my peers because each piece discussed issues or advanced perspectives that I had never before considered. I've truly never learned so much during one semester. The course is intellectually challenging, but in a rewarding--not burdensome--way. The readings literally helped to clarify/solidify some of my career aspirations because they're just that interesting and impactful! Additionally, one of the best parts of the course is Professor Collins himself! This was my second course with him, and he is such a thoughtful instructor. He provides detailed feedback to each reading response, and every sentence of your papers will be marked and commented on. It's refreshing to have a professor so committed to facilitating the intellectual development of his students. He also devotes some time each class session to review the material from the previous class in order to make sure that everyone has a strong grasp on the material, which I really appreciated; that's particularly helpful for the midterm exam and papers.
N/a

I would recommend the course only if it was being taught by Prof. Collins. He has a way of engaging with students that teases out their individual analytical skills and insights. Prof. Collins has done more for my personal intellectual project than anyone else at Yale.
Definitely, but only if you intend to actually do the readings and put some work into this course. If you do, then you really will get a ton out of it
Absolutely, Professor Collins is awesome. Almost every week covered an interesting topic and the professor always kept things interesting.
Definitely would recommend it! The readings were sometimes a lot to keep up with, but they're absolutely worth the time.
Yes! This course provides a great overview of business ethics and applies frameworks learned in other ethics classes to real life problems.
